title: Cost of Living Calculator (Salary Comparison)

seo.title: Cost of Living Calculator | Relocation Salary Comparison
seo.description: Moving to a new city? Compare rent, groceries, and salary needs. Find out if that new job offer is actually a raise or a pay cut.

summary: Is a $10,000 raise worth it if your rent doubles? Use this calculator to compare the true cost of living between two cities.

faq.a: It calculates the difference in major expenses (Housing, Food, Utilities) and adds that difference to your current salary, grossed up for taxes. It answers: 'How much do I need to earn to have the same lifestyle?'

faq.q: Where do I find the 'Price Difference' percentages?
faq.a: You can find city comparison data on sites like Numbeo or NerdWallet. For example, if Numbeo says groceries in NYC are 20% higher than in Austin, enter '20' in the Groceries field.

This tool uses a simplified tax estimate. Moving from a no-tax state (like TX or FL) to a high-tax state (like CA or NY) will have a *massive* impact not fully captured here. You should add an extra 5-10% buffer to the 'Required Salary' if moving to a high-tax jurisdiction.

faq.q: Why is housing the biggest factor?
faq.a: For most people, rent or mortgage is the single largest monthly expense. A 50% increase in rent often outweighs a 20% increase in food prices. Always secure a housing estimate before accepting a job offer.

article.heading: The Relocation Trap
article.body:
A higher salary doesn't always mean more money. If you move from Des Moines to San Francisco for a $50,000 raise, you might actually be taking a pay cut.

**The Purchasing Power Parity:**
$100,000 in a low-cost city might feel like $250,000 in a high-cost city. Your quality of life depends on your 'disposable income'—what's left after the bills are paid—not the number on your offer letter.

article.heading: The Big Three Expenses
article.body:
When comparing cities, focus on these three levers:
1.  **Housing:** This is usually the dealbreaker. Check Zillow or Apartments.com for real-time listings. Do not rely on outdated averages.
2.  **Taxes:** State income tax ranges from 0% (WA, TX, FL) to over 13% (CA). This comes directly out of your paycheck.
3.  **Commute:** A 'cheaper' house 1 hour away costs you 10 hours a week (unpaid time) plus gas and wear-and-tear.

article.heading: Salary Negotiation Leverage
article.body:
Use the output of this calculator in your salary negotiation. 

*"I'm excited about the role, but based on the 40% higher cost of living in Seattle, I would need a base salary of $X to maintain my current standard of living."*

Data is a powerful negotiation tool. It makes your request objective, not greedy.
